## 4.2.4 Radioactive contamination

- Distinguish between radioactive **contamination** and **irradiation**.
- Compare the **hazards** associated with contamination and irradiation
- Identify suitable **precautions** to take when using irradiation
- The importance of sharing data on the effects of radiation on humans, **peer review**

---

<!-- _class: upper-alpha -->

# Would you rather eat strawberries which...

![bg left fit](https://live.staticflickr.com/65535/49658296801_148f4b35e2_b.jpg)

1. have been **irradiated**?
2. are **contaminated** with radioactive material?
3. have been put **straight in the container** from the field?

## THINK, THEN DISCUSS IN PAIRS!

---

# Radioactive contamination

## Irradiation

> An object is exposed to **ionising** radiation. It does **not** become radioactive.

## Contamination

> The unwanted presence of **radioactive** atoms on other materials.

![bg right:40% contain](https://d1e4pidl3fu268.cloudfront.net/bfad0e39-d9ff-412c-8424-cd426b4f7ca8/radiationexposuretypesl.jpg)

---

# Watch the [clip from Chernobyl "Their clothes are contaminated"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=egrkuimMk-g)

- Why was it important to dispose of the clothes from the firefighters?
- Why did the nurse's hand go red?

---

# Irradiation or contamination?

---

# Alexander Litvinenko

- Poisoned by Russian agents
- Put alpha emitter in his tea

![bg right:70%](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/9/99/AlexanderLitvinenko.jpg)
![bg](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/45f44dfb141c9e0bc0ee846c8f933455dfdd8f2f/1150_973_1489_893/master/1489.jpg?width=1200&height=900&quality=85&auto=format&fit=crop&s=e49ff14c1182834389f4c9fa6c026de0)

---

# Sterilisation of medical instruments

- gamma radiation used
- kills bacteria

![bg left](https://www.lookandlearn.com/history-images/preview/YW/YW036/YW036231N_Surgical-Instruments-clamp-needle-holder.jpg)

---


# Radium girls

- painted watch faces with fluorecent radium
- often painted it on themselves

![bg right:65%](https://www.refinery29.com/images/10120706.jpg?crop=40%3A21)
![bg](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

---

# Radiotherapy

- targets gamma radiation to kill cancer cells

![bg left](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Stereotactic_body_radiotherapy_2.jpg)

---

# Task

Use the information from BBC Bitesize to help you complete the worksheet.

---

# Contamination vs. Irradiation

irradiation | contamination |
--- | --- |
is when an object is exposed to ionising radiation | is the unwanted presence of radioactive atoms
$\gamma$ radiation most dangerous because it can penetrate skin | alpha radiation most dangererous for internal contamination because it is the most ionising
can be used for **sterilisation/radiotherapy** | uses: radioactive tracers e.g. **leak detection** and **medical tracers**
object exposed does not become radioactive | contaminated objects are radioactive

---

![bg right:40%](https://live.staticflickr.com/5787/29624994423_4173f967cc_b.jpg)

# Safe handling of radioactive sources

- Watch the demonstration, and write down any **safety precautions** used in the handling and storage of the radioactive source.
- Do these precautions help to prevent irradiation, contamination, or both?

---

![bg right:40%](https://live.staticflickr.com/5787/29624994423_4173f967cc_b.jpg)

# Safety Precautions

## How many did you get?

- **lead-lined** container (irradiation)
- avoid contact with skin
- tongs to increase distance (irradiation)
- minimise exposure time (irradiation)
- gloves (contamination)
- source holder

## Did I miss any out?
